Award.AwardTitle: Spectral Multiplexing of Fiber Bragg Grating Sensors for Low-Power Optical Sensor Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is important to monitor the structural integrity and performance of large, complex structural systems throughout their service life. In-service monitoring can increase the safety of the structure and reduce downtimes for repairs. The aim of this research is to derive, implement and demonstrate a low-power, optical fiber based, strain sensor network that can be scaled up to a large number of sensors and applied for high-speed testing of large mechanical and aerospace structural systems. The low-power, high data acquisition rate sensor network will be evaluated for two critical applications of composite structures. First, crash-testing of composite automotive structures for accident survivability analysis will better enable the understanding of how these materials behave and absorb energy during a crash. The implementation of the sensor network with a large number of sensors in the automotive structure will permit a detailed analysis of the dynamic failure of the materials during the crash. Second, the sensor network will be applied to lightning strike testing of composite airframe structures. Lightning strikes pose a large problem for carbon composite materials in aircraft structures due to the inherent low conductivity of composite materials, leading to significant material damage as the converted lightning electromagnetic energy propagates through the material. The high-density sensor network will permit a detailed correlation between the lightning strike properties and the resulting material damage.

A fundamentally new method for multiplexing fiber Bragg grating sensors based on the measurement of their individual spectral properties will be derived and tested. This multiplexing strategy can be scaled to both a large number of sensors and high-speed data processing, enabling the capability to multiplex a large number of Bragg grating sensors using a single low-bandwidth, low-power, low-cost laser source. An algorithm for sensor data identification and measurement in highly multiplexed fiber Bragg grating sensor networks will be derived based on combined shape profile division multiplexing and wavelength division multiplexing, while incorporating prior knowledge of the sensor network responses for increased accuracy. The outcome of this research would be fiber Bragg grating sensor network multiplexing capabilities with power requirements orders of magnitude less than current systems, enabling future fiber Bragg grating sensor networks on wireless sensing platforms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is important to monitor the structural integrity and performance of large, complex structural systems throughout their service life. In-service monitoring can increase the safety of the structure and reduce downtimes for repairs. This research developed and demonstrated a low-power, optical fiber based, strain sensor network that can be scaled up to a large number of sensors and applied for high-speed testing of large mechanical and aerospace structural systems. The low-power, high data acquisition rate (up to 100 kHz) sensor network was evaluated in a variety of different loading conditions. First the system was tested at quasi-static loads, resting conditions, then at low speed impact to simulate tool drop or a low speed accident. Finally, the system was evaluated using a high-speed impact, which would be like a high-speed car crash. At all testing speeds independent measurement were performed to determine the accuracy and precision of the system.  This integrated system will enable the understanding of how these materials behave and absorb energy during a crash and their integrity after impact. The implementation of the sensor network with a large number of sensors in the automotive structure will permit a detailed analysis of the dynamic failure of the materials during the crash. 

 

To further test the system a simulated lightning strike methodology was created. Typically testing requires expensive equipment, so a simplified system that uses a shock tube (pressure pulse) and rapid heating (current dump) was developed to simulate the response. Lightning strikes pose a large problem for carbon composite materials in aircraft structures due to the inherent low conductivity of composite materials, leading to significant material damage as the converted lightning electromagnetic energy propagates through the material. The high-density sensor network will permit a detailed correlation between the lightning strike properties and the resulting material damage. Testing showed a correlation between the increase in temperature associated with lightning strike and the degradation of the composite material. 


In order to increase the throughput of the system and gather an array of data a fundamentally new method for multiplexing fiber Bragg grating sensors based on the measurement of their individual spectral properties was derived and tested. This multiplexing strategy can be scaled to both a large number of sensors and high-speed data processing, enabling the capability to multiplex a large number of Bragg grating sensors using a single low-bandwidth, low-power, low-cost laser source. An algorithm for sensor data identification and measurement in highly multiplexed fiber Bragg grating sensor networks was derived based on combined shape profile division multiplexing and wavelength division multiplexing, while incorporating prior knowledge of the sensor network responses for increased accuracy. 

 

The research resulted in two major outcomes the first was a fiber Bragg grating sensor network with multiplexing capabilities with power requirements orders of magnitude less than current systems, enabling future fiber Bragg grating sensor networks on wireless sensing platforms. The second was a new methodology to rapidly and quickly test the response of materials to lightning strike with the ability to isolate the mechanisms from the shock wave and rapid heating to understand the effect of each and the interaction that occurs. 

 

There were five journal papers as a result of this work and four conference presentations. Three different graduate students worked on this project and six different undergraduates were given the opportunity to perform research for the first time. This research also interacted with an REU Site that we had on composite in extreme environments.
